subtitle: TRANSCRIPT
full_transcript:
[10.2s - 16.5s]: Welcome to the Y Honors Community Podcast. I'm your host, Aaron William Perry. And today,

[16.8s - 22.3s]: we're visiting with the founder of Capital Institute, John Fullerton. Hey, John.

[23.1s - 28.7s]: Hey, good afternoon, Aaron. How are you doing today? I'm good. I'm good. Merry Christmas. Happy

[28.7s - 34.7s]: holidays. Merry Christmas. Happy holidays to you as well. Really looking forward to our discussion

[34.7s - 42.5s]: today about regenerative economics and finance and obviously a very, very important topic right

[42.5s - 52.4s]: now. I hope so. Yes. John Fullerton is an unconventional economist, impact investor,

[52.4s - 59.7s]: writer and some have said philosopher building on and integrating the work of many. He is the architect

[59.7s - 65.8s]: of regenerative economics first conceived in his 2015 booklet called regenerative capitalism,

[66.3s - 72.4s]: how universal patterns and principles will shape the new economy. After a successful 20-year career

[72.4s - 77.6s]: on Wall Street, where he was a managing director of what he calls the old JP Morgan,

[77.6s - 84.6s]: John listened to a persistent inner voice and walked away in 2001 with no plan, but many questions.

[85.5s - 92.1s]: A few months later, he experienced 9-11 firsthand. The questions crystallized into his life's work

[92.1s - 97.5s]: with the creation of the Capital Institute in 2010, where his work reflects the rising

[97.5s - 103.1s]: evolutionary shift in consciousness from modern age thinking to integral age thinking.

[103.9s - 110.5s]: Capital Institute is dedicated to the bold reimagination of economics and finance and service to life,

[110.6s - 117.2s]: guided by the universal patterns and principles that describe how all healthy living systems that sustain themselves

[117.2s - 124.2s]: in the real world actually work. The promise of regenerative economics and finance is to unlock the profound

[124.2s - 131.8s]: and presently unseen potential. That is the source of our future prosperity and the reason for hope in our troubled times.

[132.5s - 138.3s]: During his Wall Street career, John managed numerous capital markets and derivatives businesses around the globe

[138.8s - 145.6s]: and was JP Morgan's oversight committee representative that managed the rescue of long-term capital management in 1998

[145.6s - 150.4s]: and finally was chief investment officer for Lab Morgan before retiring from the firm.

[151.0s - 159.9s]: A committed impact investor, John is the chairman of New Day Enterprises, PBC, and the co-founder of Grasslands LLC.

[160.9s - 169.8s]: He is a board member of FirstCrop, the Savory Institute, and Stoneaker's Farm, is an advisor to numerous sustainability initiatives

[169.8s - 179.7s]: and is a member of the Club of Rome. John speaks internationally to public audiences and universities and writes a monthly blog, The Future of Finance.

[180.2s - 186.2s]: John, welcome to the show and really a pleasure to have this opportunity to speak with you.

[186.9s - 193.7s]: I want to dive right in by asking you what is regenerative economics and regenerative finance?

[194.6s - 198.3s]: It is a pleasure to be with you, Aaron, and with your audience.

[200.7s - 210.3s]: The privilege, I should say, I think this is an idea whose time is finally coming, so it's a great privilege to be able to share my contribution in thinking on it.

[211.5s - 214.9s]: The idea of regenerative economics is quite simple.

[216.2s - 223.7s]: It is that our current economic system is obviously fraught with problems.

[224.6s - 237.6s]: Most of the work we see trying to fix those problems are largely incremental fixes, one could say even closing the barn door after the horse is left.

[239.1s - 251.4s]: The idea of regenerative economics is really a departure from incremental change to say what if we considered the human economy as a living system?

[252.4s - 268.9s]: We looked to real living systems in the real world, such as your body and my body or ecosystems, and discerned the patterns and principles that make them sustainable, and then applied those same patterns and principles to the human economy.

[268.9s - 274.4s]: What would that teach us about the direction we need to move the economy?

[275.3s - 285.2s]: Then applying those same patterns and principles to our financial system on the assumption that the financial system actually needs to work in service of a regenerative economy.

[286.2s - 293.5s]: It is essentially a living system science which happens to be remarkably aligned with our indigenous wisdom, I should add.

[294.5s - 303.6s]: Applying that knowledge to economics as opposed to accepting the unquestioned assumptions of economics.

[305.3s - 306.6s]: Yes, thank you.

[306.8s - 326.3s]: I am so excited to ask you a number of questions today because it seems clearly that we are at a stage now where our economic activity at the global scale is undermining the very life support systems upon which we all depend.

[327.3s - 338.2s]: This is not an academic exercise. This really is a fundamental issue challenge and the opportunity that we are facing as a species at this juncture in time.

[339.4s - 352.5s]: I am curious to ask you, you just mentioned indigenous wisdom. What is your view as an individual human being on where we stand right now as a species?

[353.5s - 362.1s]: How we got here and I am sensing there is a bigger kind of arc of time and history that informs some of your thinking.

[363.5s - 369.9s]: Yes, absolutely. I am a student of that question and still searching.

[372.0s - 387.7s]: I have come to believe that this idea was sort of arrogance of the present moment that we humans always think that our moment in time is the most important blah, blah, blah.

[388.7s - 407.2s]: I have rejected that. I have resisted that for years and I have slowly come to believe and believe very strongly that we are at a pivotable, epic defining moment.

[408.2s - 419.1s]: It is not a moment necessarily that lasts a year or three years or even 25 years. It may last longer than that. It has probably started in the 60s.

[420.4s - 446.7s]: I have come to believe that we are at the end of the modern age to put it bluntly. The modern age with all of its great advances in progress of science and the arts and an economic design that grew in the context of the modern age, the scientific science really.

[448.1s - 458.4s]: We have reached its natural limit just as we have reached natural limits of the middle ages and the ancient period before that.

[458.6s - 470.0s]: I am speaking just of Western culture. There is no reason to think that history ends with the Western modern age. What was that book that someone wrote years ago at the end of history?

[470.0s - 484.2s]: I am talking about an arrogant idea. I think we are in this transition. When the enlightenment happened, the people living through that period, no one told them it was the enlightenment.

[484.2s - 496.5s]: It was a very exciting dynamic and scary time because a lot of what people thought to be true was being questioned and reassessed.

[496.7s - 505.9s]: I think we are in a very exciting moment like that with very serious consequences depending on how we handle it.

[506.9s - 522.0s]: There are a lot of people talking about the intergal age and that is probably speaking, integrating our knowledge together is going to define this next age, whatever it gets called once the historians write the history.

[523.0s - 543.9s]: I believe that this is a sub-age before the intergal age. We either grab onto this regenerative paradigm and get out of the hole we are in or go back into another dark age.

[545.6s - 552.3s]: I do not say that lightly. I mean, I literally mean that, but another dark age does not mean the end of humanity.

[554.1s - 561.0s]: We have been through a dark age before and there is no reason to suggest we could not go into another one.

[561.8s - 578.0s]: I think we are at the moment in time where we are going to collectively choose whether that happens based on our actions and behaviors and the way we see ourselves in the world in the next half century if not next 10 years.

[579.8s - 581.7s]: Thank you for sharing that.

[582.3s - 587.5s]: I think we are going to have a lot of people talking about what you are saying resonates with me and my perspective.

[588.6s - 597.9s]: I have to ask on behalf of some of my skeptical colleagues back in grad school and we are talking about sustainable economic development and these sorts of things.

[598.9s - 611.1s]: There has been these like Malthusian, Neomalthusian cycles, the club of Rome being a well-known example of one that has been sort of pegged or labeled Neomalthusian.

[612.1s - 624.1s]: There is a point of view that says, well, new technologies and innovations will always overcome otherwise apparent limits to growth is often the phrase that is used.

[624.1s - 635.1s]: I don't agree with that perspective but I am curious when you get those kinds of questions or that kind of push back, what do you generally say in response?

[636.3s - 647.4s]: For sure there is a requirement of modernity to have that point of view.

[648.5s - 655.7s]: It is embedded in the world view of modernity that we will solve whatever comes along.

[656.7s - 667.2s]: I would say that I have studied that question quite deeply, much deeper than most of the folks who reject it very quickly.

[668.3s - 679.9s]: It sounds like you have as well but there is literally no evidence to suggest that let me back up one step further.

[679.9s - 688.9s]: You mentioned the club of Rome and the Limits to Growth study which has been incredibly influential on my own thinking which won't surprise you.

[690.1s - 703.7s]: It turns out that the Limits to Growth models that were written or created in the 1970s, 1970s have been tested many times since then.

[703.7s - 715.7s]: There was a quite authoritative research paper done by an Australian academic, I can't remember his name, maybe within the last five years or so.

[716.8s - 728.1s]: They pretty much validated the Limits to Growth models which were extremely primitive by current complexity model comparison.

[729.1s - 739.7s]: They pretty much validated what their kind of steady business as usual scenario suggested back in 1973 or whenever they published the book.

[740.8s - 746.5s]: First of all, Limits to Growth was not wrong, it is actually remarkably prescient.

[747.3s - 763.8s]: The reasons for that are quite technical and complicated but the simple example is that yes we have all kinds of technological progress but we tend to use that to use more energy, more space, more land, more.

[764.8s - 773.1s]: We don't capture the technological advances to address the problems that we are trying to resolve.

[773.4s - 777.8s]: We push ourselves to a higher living standard.

[780.9s - 791.1s]: We still get 20 miles a gallon on a combustion engine even though the thing goes wicked fast and wicked far and with a whole bunch of technology.

[792.4s - 798.3s]: This is well documented in something called the rebound effect which goes back to the collage.

[800.5s - 810.2s]: The real killer is that even if we were to capture the efficiencies, for example in our energy use, that leads us with more money.

[811.2s - 815.0s]: Here is where the crux of the matter comes into a finance guy.

[815.9s - 822.9s]: With more money we buy more stuff or invest more which has an ecological footprint.

[823.9s - 843.0s]: The more the techno optimists are right, the more we actually exacerbate our problem which is that our money, our investment capital, the way we use it today to grow the economy makes the problem worse.

[843.7s - 847.3s]: In other words, we are chasing our tail and we can never catch it.

[848.2s - 853.1s]: There is a compounding feedback loop effect in that type of system.

[854.0s - 858.9s]: Compounding is an important word. The pandemic has taught us what that actually means.

[859.9s - 872.6s]: It is a slow but steady, impossible energy to confront.

[873.0s - 879.5s]: If you have a system that is unsustainable and compounding, it is only a question of time.

[879.5s - 887.7s]: As my friend Vincent Stanley likes to say when the way you go bankrupt slowly and then quickly.

[888.2s - 890.7s]: That is really interesting.

[890.7s - 907.5s]: You have articulated a framework that presents us an alternative pathway to the trajectory that we have been on for many decades, many generations now.

[907.5s - 915.7s]: I would like to invite you if you would to walk us through the regenerative economic framework that you have articulated.

[916.3s - 924.1s]: If you do not mind, speak to the 8 principles that identify and describe that framework.

[925.7s - 928.4s]: I always struggle to do this concisely.

[928.6s - 932.2s]: Maybe I will talk about a couple of them as examples.

[932.8s - 952.7s]: I think the first and most important idea is to recognize the limitations of modern age scientific thinking, which is this idea of the reductionist method, where we take what is complicated and reduce it into pieces and parts that we can get our heads around.

[953.7s - 962.3s]: In many ways, whether you are talking about our healthcare system, our education system, our legal system, or our economy.

[963.9s - 975.5s]: They are all the result of this reductionist method, which was the key to the scientific revolution and all of the quote progress that we have made.

[977.3s - 981.4s]: My colleague, Peter Brown, likes to say that economics is bankrupt.

[983.2s - 988.0s]: It might be more accurate to say that economics is insolvenous.

[988.4s - 993.2s]: Insolvency means where you have liabilities that become bigger than the assets.

[994.2s - 998.5s]: I am not going to throw out all of economics and suggest that it is all bad.

[1000.1s - 1017.5s]: I am going to suggest that the limitations and the flaws of our economic thinking are now so profound and so great that they outweigh the many considerable strengths that economic thinking has.

[1017.5s - 1027.6s]: If you have a bankrupt way of thinking and seeing the world, you have to go back to first principles.

[1027.6s - 1048.4s]: As I mentioned earlier, the core idea is to assume and assert that the human economy, which, after all, is made up of human beings, which are by definition living systems, to assert that the human economy to be sustainable needs to behave the way other living systems behave.

[1049.4s - 1062.1s]: It turns out that the scientists who have studied living systems, while this is not as black and white as law of gravity, it is more complex.

[1063.1s - 1073.5s]: But the living system scientists will concur or have concurred that there are general patterns and principles that describe the way living systems work.

[1073.8s - 1080.3s]: Like, for example, the importance of symbiotic win-win relationships in living systems.

[1080.3s - 1089.9s]: For example, the cells in every organ in our body are working in symbiotic relationship with each other and they become part of a bigger whole.

[1090.1s - 1101.2s]: They themselves are whole and they are part of a bigger whole called an organ, which is part of a bigger whole called the cardiovascular system, which again is part of a bigger whole called our human body.

[1102.2s - 1112.9s]: And our human body isn't even all of us because there's the whole consciousness and spiritual piece of it and our self and our souls.

[1114.0s - 1127.7s]: But the idea is that the construct of living systems are these right relationships where the whole is greater than the sum of the parts.

[1127.7s - 1131.8s]: And the parts work toward the health of the whole.

[1132.7s - 1135.6s]: Now, we could talk for another hour just on that one principle.

[1137.2s - 1145.2s]: There's no living system scientists that would disagree with what I just said. They might say it differently. They probably say it better, but they wouldn't disagree with it.

[1146.2s - 1159.0s]: And by the way, there's no indigenous culture in the world that would say that's wrong. They would undoubtedly say it better and more elegant and mythical way.

[1159.8s - 1165.2s]: But the idea of our relationship with Mother Earth is not a new idea.

[1166.2s - 1187.8s]: And yet, if you apply that to our economic thinking, you find all kinds of examples of where we operate in extractive relationships as opposed to generative or constructive relationships and no more nowhere more so than in Wall Street.

[1188.7s - 1194.9s]: And in fact, the entire and here's where the principles are so critical.

[1196.4s - 1215.0s]: We in finance, you know, the sustainable finance movement is largely about creating increased transparency in markets so that investors can better adjudicate which companies should do well and which ones shouldn't.

[1215.0s - 1222.2s]: And so this whole ESG movement has arisen to address that very relevant need.

[1223.0s - 1233.8s]: But the problem is there's no amount of transparency that can fix a broken relationship between owners of big enterprises and those big enterprises.

[1233.8s - 1243.3s]: And because of the pursuit of efficient capital markets and I'll come back to efficiency in a second, we now have an ownership model, which isn't ownership at all.

[1243.7s - 1249.8s]: It's basically massive funds trading stocks, but no one actually owning big companies.

[1250.5s - 1256.3s]: And if they own them, they own an interest in them for anywhere from a nanosecond to a month to a year.

[1257.3s - 1275.1s]: But unlike say a private company where there's a family that owns the business, there really isn't any relationship much less a right relationship between the owners of enterprise and enterprise in the most powerful institution that humans have ever created the public corporation.

[1276.1s - 1293.3s]: So by getting clear on the principle of right relationship, we can see that our entire structure of corporate ownership in the biggest companies in the world is in conflict with living systems.

[1293.8s - 1307.9s]: And we can then debate whether that's terrible, not so great, not so bad or fine. But we have to acknowledge that that the way we've set things up is in conflict with the way living systems actually work because there is no relationship there.

[1309.6s - 1318.9s]: And so the idea of getting clear on principles is to identify at a root cause level where the sources of change need to come from.

[1320.0s - 1331.5s]: The other principles, I'll just mention them by name briefly and then maybe talk about one other one. But the other ones are the idea of balance systems need to be in balance.

[1332.5s - 1352.7s]: The idea of place in my language honors community in place, living systems existing place. And so a human economy needs somehow to be connected to and relevant to place both geological reality and cultural history of place.

[1353.4s - 1363.8s]: You think about globalization that has run run rough shot over that principle and no wonder the globalization turns out isn't working so well because it's in conflict with that principle.

[1364.7s - 1372.2s]: Another principle from living systems is is known as the edge effect. And you know, we hear a lot about the importance of diversity.

[1373.0s - 1395.4s]: Diversity happens in living systems at the edges between different systems. So for example, where a river meets a notion is a marsh and a marsh land is filled with diversity and diversity is is the source of life. It's also where danger exists. But, but but living systems have an abundance of life at the edges.

[1395.4s - 1406.3s]: So what does that say about a human economy and the edge between, for example, one industry and another, or the edge between the public sector and the private sector or the philanthropic sector and the public sector.

[1407.3s - 1409.0s]: Another principle is.

[1410.3s - 1422.9s]: And here's one that I kind of made up in the context of human economies, I in my language, it's is holistic wealth. So some economy is largely about the.

[1423.7s - 1434.6s]: At least the way we've thought about it is the the creation of wealth and yet we've reduced that to the creation of money. We think that the purpose of the economy is to get money.

[1436.5s - 1446.0s]: And so this is a reminder that the true wealth is not money money is a human artifact, but, but wealth needs to be holistically understood.

[1447.0s - 1457.0s]: And then another one is again in my language robust circulation. This is the idea that that an economy like a living system needs to behave like a healthy metabolism.

[1457.8s - 1470.0s]: It's not merely circular thinking, although circular flows are important. It's actually much more important to think about metabolism as needing healthy inputs.

[1470.0s - 1485.0s]: So the food into the system needs to be the right food and healthy food, not toxic food. The way is going out of the system can't spoil the nest. So too much CO2 in the atmosphere is in conflict with living systems principles.

[1485.4s - 1491.9s]: It can't possibly be in alignment with a sustainable economy and so forth.

[1491.9s - 1503.5s]: I did want to just I don't know if I probably haven't mentioned all eight of them, but I'm, you know, I don't want to sort of blab on here too long you get the idea they're all on.

[1504.2s - 1517.7s]: Yeah, it's great. John and just to interject you've articulated six of the eight leaving two remaining one is empowered participation and one is innovative adaptive responsive.

[1518.3s - 1521.6s]: So I just since we're going through my figured why not round it out.

[1521.7s - 1540.2s]: Yeah, put them out there. I mean, innovative responsive. That's sort of a completely non controversial one, right? I mean, I think the, but but again, the importance of small business and entrepreneurs in contrast with the importance of monopolies and big industrial, powerful giants.

[1540.2s - 1551.2s]: We, we have public policies that tend to support the monopolists because they have lobbying power and much more than we support entrepreneurs and small businesses.

[1551.6s - 1559.5s]: This is not just an opinion that wow, we should do it differently. This is saying, well, that's actually the way living systems work. So we need to do it differently.

[1560.3s - 1562.8s]: And empowered participation. I'll just comment very quickly.

[1563.3s - 1571.4s]: You know, this one is quite profound. Again, this is a description of real living systems, a quality of real living systems.

[1572.6s - 1581.5s]: And what's true about them is that all parts of that system are empowered or self-empowered to participate in the health of that system.

[1582.2s - 1585.3s]: That's not just good for that part. That's good for the health of the system.

[1585.3s - 1596.5s]: So, for example, I always, when I give talks, I say, well, if my feet are not empowered to participate in the circulation of oxygen in my body, that's terrible for my feet.

[1596.9s - 1602.8s]: But that's also terrible for me because I won't be able to walk. And if I can't walk, I can't fulfill my potential as a human being.

[1603.6s - 1612.7s]: So this gets to this whole issue of inequality. Inequality is no longer simply a moral question that we can have different opinions on.

[1612.7s - 1625.7s]: It's actually a direct threat to systemic health. And all you have to do is look at what's happened in the world in the last 12 months to see that that's actually true.

[1626.5s - 1641.0s]: But living systems principles would tell us that inequality that is so extreme that it disempowers the participation of the broad populations of the world,

[1641.0s - 1651.2s]: and the world of the world, to contribute to and receive benefits from the system means that systemic health is undermined. And ultimately, it will hurt all parts of the system.

[1651.6s - 1670.7s]: So I think we're seeing that play out in the real world. And rather than debate whether we can afford to, you know, whether we need to do austerity or whether we can afford the debt, we need to start by saying, well, we can't afford to have half of the planet disempowered from the health of the economy.

[1670.7s - 1672.9s]: That economy will not survive.

[1674.3s - 1684.6s]: Yeah, thank you very much for running through that. And of course, for emphasizing the critical importance of the empowered participation.

[1684.6s - 1699.0s]: And look, just because there's an ecological reason behind why empowered participation is critical, that doesn't mean that there's not also a moral.

[1699.4s - 1701.8s]: Appalition, right? Isn't it wonderful that they're aligned?

[1702.3s - 1703.2s]: Yes, yes.

[1703.2s - 1716.0s]: So we don't have to debate the moral, because, you know, for some reason, you know, I mean, obviously, I'm pretty confident most people that have tuned into this conversation would have a shared view on the moral question.

[1716.6s - 1724.6s]: But that isn't a shared view across the world, or we wouldn't be, we wouldn't tolerate the current levels of inequality.

[1724.6s - 1734.1s]: And I think a lot of the people in the capitalist system that tolerated would really prefer it not be there.

[1734.1s - 1745.9s]: They would just argue that fixing it, you know, the cure will be worse than the disease, as opposed to literally thinking that this extreme inequality is a positive attribute.

[1747.1s - 1767.1s]: Yeah, it's so interesting. And that that kind of gets at a question I want to ask you, and I'll formulate it with a couple of steps here. I, by the way, just love the edge effect and abundance piece as one of the eight principles, because it reminds me of my permaculture studies.

[1767.1s - 1773.5s]: So, 25 years ago, right, and that was a really important piece that Bill Molison articulated.

[1775.1s - 1788.2s]: And the robust circulation, of course, reminds me of the work by our mutual departed friend Bernard Leotard with his book Future of Money.

[1788.2s - 1790.0s]: And I want to chat about that in a few minutes.

[1791.1s - 1808.8s]: But as you were describing the metabolism metaphor for this robust circulation requirement, it made me think that the, the hyper accumulation of financial resources might be very much like the hyper accumulation of toxins in a body or an ecosystem.

[1809.6s - 1813.9s]: And I wanted to, I wanted to ask you to riff on that for a little bit.

[1814.4s - 1814.5s]: Yeah.

[1815.2s - 1827.1s]: So, I mean, you introduced a couple of thoughts, you know, key thoughts. One is that, first of all, I should say, these are not, these eight are not the kind of correct answer.

[1827.1s - 1841.0s]: They're, they're a map. And as Nora Bateson reminded me recently, the map is not the territory, which is a famous expression that goes back, I forget to, to who wrote that.

[1841.1s - 1855.8s]: But they're a map that is useful to me. It's proven to be useful to others, but it doesn't mean that it's correct and an accurate map. It's a, it's a tool that can be used for our collective learning.

[1857.1s - 1868.6s]: And secondly, it's not linear that, you know, we're dealing with a complex system. So it's not like let's go with principle number one, check principle number two, check, they all interrelate together.

[1868.6s - 1882.7s]: So the, the, the idea of wealth accumulation being in conflict with circulation is also in conflict with imbalance. It's also in conflict with, um,

[1884.1s - 1910.5s]: empower our rather honor, community in place because of all the money is sitting in an account on Wall Street. It's obviously not circulating out into the capillaries of the system. So, the, the massive accumulation of wealth in a very few hands is probably in conflict with all eight principles. If we really thought through it, but, you know, the term, necrosis, I think I'm saying correctly, where you know, blood clots.

[1911.5s - 1940.4s]: What, you know, whether it's toxins building up, we could have an interesting debate about whether money is, is a toxin. I think I think it's, it's probably a both end, you know, money used in a, in a constructive way is a very valuable tool, but money used either inappropriately or, or just sitting is actually, you know, it's, you know, it's a very important thing.

[1940.5s - 1962.9s]: It's in violation of the circulation requirement. So yeah, I mean, and people have understood this for a long time, right? I mean, the, the whole idea of the georgist economics idea of, of taxing land speculation, but so that people wouldn't hoard land and, and take it out of the constructive use of a broad number of people.

[1963.9s - 1985.2s]: And so, you know, a lot of these ideas are actually just reminding us of what we've always known, but have seemed to have forgotten in the current late modern age context, which seems like it's inevitably true, but isn't necessarily inevitably true and hasn't always been true.

[1986.5s - 2000.1s]: But, but I think, you know, West Jackson once said that, you know, we have to keep money out of carbon trouble. And what he meant by that, and here's sort of tying money to your toxin idea.

[2000.1s - 2012.2s]: If, if we're honest when, when individuals or institutions have a lot of money, they tend to use more carbon or they tend to burn more carbon.

[2013.0s - 2027.4s]: Now, it's not intentional. It's just that with an individual, their lifestyle, if it's an institution, their ambitions tend to be energy intensive. And when we have a fossil fuel based energy system, that means their carbon burning carbon intensive.

[2027.9s - 2053.7s]: So, in a sense, money is toxic. And, and you know, if, if you're a super wealthy individual and you're flying around on your private jet to go to dinner and you're having a yacht parked in two parts of the world, you know, you're burning a lot of carbon. segments.text: Welcome to the Y Honors Community Podcast. I'm your host, Aaron William Perry. And today,
we're visiting with the founder of Capital Institute, John Fullerton. Hey, John.
Hey, good afternoon, Aaron. How are you doing today? I'm good. I'm good. Merry Christmas. Happy
holidays. Merry Christmas. Happy holidays to you as well. Really looking forward to our discussion
today about regenerative economics and finance and obviously a very, very important topic right
now. I hope so. Yes. John Fullerton is an unconventional economist, impact investor,
writer and some have said philosopher building on and integrating the work of many. He is the architect
of regenerative economics first conceived in his 2015 booklet called regenerative capitalism,
how universal patterns and principles will shape the new economy. After a successful 20-year career
on Wall Street, where he was a managing director of what he calls the old JP Morgan,
John listened to a persistent inner voice and walked away in 2001 with no plan, but many questions.
A few months later, he experienced 9-11 firsthand. The questions crystallized into his life's work
with the creation of the Capital Institute in 2010, where his work reflects the rising
evolutionary shift in consciousness from modern age thinking to integral age thinking.
Capital Institute is dedicated to the bold reimagination of economics and finance and service to life,
guided by the universal patterns and principles that describe how all healthy living systems that sustain themselves
in the real world actually work. The promise of regenerative economics and finance is to unlock the profound
and presently unseen potential. That is the source of our future prosperity and the reason for hope in our troubled times.
During his Wall Street career, John managed numerous capital markets and derivatives businesses around the globe
and was JP Morgan's oversight committee representative that managed the rescue of long-term capital management in 1998
and finally was chief investment officer for Lab Morgan before retiring from the firm.
A committed impact investor, John is the chairman of New Day Enterprises, PBC, and the co-founder of Grasslands LLC.
He is a board member of FirstCrop, the Savory Institute, and Stoneaker's Farm, is an advisor to numerous sustainability initiatives
and is a member of the Club of Rome. John speaks internationally to public audiences and universities and writes a monthly blog, The Future of Finance.
John, welcome to the show and really a pleasure to have this opportunity to speak with you.
I want to dive right in by asking you what is regenerative economics and regenerative finance?
It is a pleasure to be with you, Aaron, and with your audience.
The privilege, I should say, I think this is an idea whose time is finally coming, so it's a great privilege to be able to share my contribution in thinking on it.
The idea of regenerative economics is quite simple.
It is that our current economic system is obviously fraught with problems.
Most of the work we see trying to fix those problems are largely incremental fixes, one could say even closing the barn door after the horse is left.
The idea of regenerative economics is really a departure from incremental change to say what if we considered the human economy as a living system?

We looked to real living systems in the real world, such as your body and my body or ecosystems, and discerned the patterns and principles that make them sustainable, and then applied those same patterns and principles to the human economy.
What would that teach us about the direction we need to move the economy?
Then applying those same patterns and principles to our financial system on the assumption that the financial system actually needs to work in service of a regenerative economy.
It is essentially a living system science which happens to be remarkably aligned with our indigenous wisdom, I should add.
Applying that knowledge to economics as opposed to accepting the unquestioned assumptions of economics.
Yes, thank you.

I am so excited to ask you a number of questions today because it seems clearly that we are at a stage now where our economic activity at the global scale is undermining the very life support systems upon which we all depend.
This is not an academic exercise. This really is a fundamental issue challenge and the opportunity that we are facing as a species at this juncture in time.
I am curious to ask you, you just mentioned indigenous wisdom. What is your view as an individual human being on where we stand right now as a species?
How we got here and I am sensing there is a bigger kind of arc of time and history that informs some of your thinking.
Yes, absolutely. I am a student of that question and still searching.
I have come to believe that this idea was sort of arrogance of the present moment that we humans always think that our moment in time is the most important blah, blah, blah.
I have rejected that. I have resisted that for years and I have slowly come to believe and believe very strongly that we are at a pivotable, epic defining moment.
It is not a moment necessarily that lasts a year or three years or even 25 years. It may last longer than that. It has probably started in the 60s.

I have come to believe that we are at the end of the modern age to put it bluntly. The modern age with all of its great advances in progress of science and the arts and an economic design that grew in the context of the modern age, the scientific science really.
We have reached its natural limit just as we have reached natural limits of the middle ages and the ancient period before that.
I am speaking just of Western culture. There is no reason to think that history ends with the Western modern age. What was that book that someone wrote years ago at the end of history?
I am talking about an arrogant idea. I think we are in this transition. When the enlightenment happened, the people living through that period, no one told them it was the enlightenment.
It was a very exciting dynamic and scary time because a lot of what people thought to be true was being questioned and reassessed.
I think we are in a very exciting moment like that with very serious consequences depending on how we handle it.

There are a lot of people talking about the intergal age and that is probably speaking, integrating our knowledge together is going to define this next age, whatever it gets called once the historians write the history.
I believe that this is a sub-age before the intergal age. We either grab onto this regenerative paradigm and get out of the hole we are in or go back into another dark age.
I do not say that lightly. I mean, I literally mean that, but another dark age does not mean the end of humanity.
We have been through a dark age before and there is no reason to suggest we could not go into another one.

I think we are at the moment in time where we are going to collectively choose whether that happens based on our actions and behaviors and the way we see ourselves in the world in the next half century if not next 10 years.
Thank you for sharing that.
I think we are going to have a lot of people talking about what you are saying resonates with me and my perspective.
I have to ask on behalf of some of my skeptical colleagues back in grad school and we are talking about sustainable economic development and these sorts of things.
There has been these like Malthusian, Neomalthusian cycles, the club of Rome being a well-known example of one that has been sort of pegged or labeled Neomalthusian.
There is a point of view that says, well, new technologies and innovations will always overcome otherwise apparent limits to growth is often the phrase that is used.
I don't agree with that perspective but I am curious when you get those kinds of questions or that kind of push back, what do you generally say in response?
For sure there is a requirement of modernity to have that point of view.
It is embedded in the world view of modernity that we will solve whatever comes along.
I would say that I have studied that question quite deeply, much deeper than most of the folks who reject it very quickly.
It sounds like you have as well but there is literally no evidence to suggest that let me back up one step further.
You mentioned the club of Rome and the Limits to Growth study which has been incredibly influential on my own thinking which won't surprise you.
It turns out that the Limits to Growth models that were written or created in the 1970s, 1970s have been tested many times since then.
There was a quite authoritative research paper done by an Australian academic, I can't remember his name, maybe within the last five years or so.
They pretty much validated the Limits to Growth models which were extremely primitive by current complexity model comparison.
They pretty much validated what their kind of steady business as usual scenario suggested back in 1973 or whenever they published the book.
First of all, Limits to Growth was not wrong, it is actually remarkably prescient.

The reasons for that are quite technical and complicated but the simple example is that yes we have all kinds of technological progress but we tend to use that to use more energy, more space, more land, more.
We don't capture the technological advances to address the problems that we are trying to resolve.
We push ourselves to a higher living standard.
We still get 20 miles a gallon on a combustion engine even though the thing goes wicked fast and wicked far and with a whole bunch of technology.
This is well documented in something called the rebound effect which goes back to the collage.
The real killer is that even if we were to capture the efficiencies, for example in our energy use, that leads us with more money.
Here is where the crux of the matter comes into a finance guy.
With more money we buy more stuff or invest more which has an ecological footprint.

The more the techno optimists are right, the more we actually exacerbate our problem which is that our money, our investment capital, the way we use it today to grow the economy makes the problem worse.
In other words, we are chasing our tail and we can never catch it.
There is a compounding feedback loop effect in that type of system.
Compounding is an important word. The pandemic has taught us what that actually means.
It is a slow but steady, impossible energy to confront.
If you have a system that is unsustainable and compounding, it is only a question of time.
As my friend Vincent Stanley likes to say when the way you go bankrupt slowly and then quickly.
That is really interesting.
You have articulated a framework that presents us an alternative pathway to the trajectory that we have been on for many decades, many generations now.
I would like to invite you if you would to walk us through the regenerative economic framework that you have articulated.
If you do not mind, speak to the 8 principles that identify and describe that framework.
I always struggle to do this concisely.
Maybe I will talk about a couple of them as examples.

I think the first and most important idea is to recognize the limitations of modern age scientific thinking, which is this idea of the reductionist method, where we take what is complicated and reduce it into pieces and parts that we can get our heads around.
In many ways, whether you are talking about our healthcare system, our education system, our legal system, or our economy.
They are all the result of this reductionist method, which was the key to the scientific revolution and all of the quote progress that we have made.
My colleague, Peter Brown, likes to say that economics is bankrupt.
It might be more accurate to say that economics is insolvenous.
Insolvency means where you have liabilities that become bigger than the assets.
I am not going to throw out all of economics and suggest that it is all bad.
I am going to suggest that the limitations and the flaws of our economic thinking are now so profound and so great that they outweigh the many considerable strengths that economic thinking has.
If you have a bankrupt way of thinking and seeing the world, you have to go back to first principles.

As I mentioned earlier, the core idea is to assume and assert that the human economy, which, after all, is made up of human beings, which are by definition living systems, to assert that the human economy to be sustainable needs to behave the way other living systems behave.
It turns out that the scientists who have studied living systems, while this is not as black and white as law of gravity, it is more complex.
But the living system scientists will concur or have concurred that there are general patterns and principles that describe the way living systems work.
Like, for example, the importance of symbiotic win-win relationships in living systems.
For example, the cells in every organ in our body are working in symbiotic relationship with each other and they become part of a bigger whole.

They themselves are whole and they are part of a bigger whole called an organ, which is part of a bigger whole called the cardiovascular system, which again is part of a bigger whole called our human body.
And our human body isn't even all of us because there's the whole consciousness and spiritual piece of it and our self and our souls.
But the idea is that the construct of living systems are these right relationships where the whole is greater than the sum of the parts.
And the parts work toward the health of the whole.
Now, we could talk for another hour just on that one principle.
There's no living system scientists that would disagree with what I just said. They might say it differently. They probably say it better, but they wouldn't disagree with it.
And by the way, there's no indigenous culture in the world that would say that's wrong. They would undoubtedly say it better and more elegant and mythical way.
But the idea of our relationship with Mother Earth is not a new idea.

And yet, if you apply that to our economic thinking, you find all kinds of examples of where we operate in extractive relationships as opposed to generative or constructive relationships and no more nowhere more so than in Wall Street.
And in fact, the entire and here's where the principles are so critical.

We in finance, you know, the sustainable finance movement is largely about creating increased transparency in markets so that investors can better adjudicate which companies should do well and which ones shouldn't.
And so this whole ESG movement has arisen to address that very relevant need.
But the problem is there's no amount of transparency that can fix a broken relationship between owners of big enterprises and those big enterprises.
And because of the pursuit of efficient capital markets and I'll come back to efficiency in a second, we now have an ownership model, which isn't ownership at all.
It's basically massive funds trading stocks, but no one actually owning big companies.
And if they own them, they own an interest in them for anywhere from a nanosecond to a month to a year.

But unlike say a private company where there's a family that owns the business, there really isn't any relationship much less a right relationship between the owners of enterprise and enterprise in the most powerful institution that humans have ever created the public corporation.
So by getting clear on the principle of right relationship, we can see that our entire structure of corporate ownership in the biggest companies in the world is in conflict with living systems.

And we can then debate whether that's terrible, not so great, not so bad or fine. But we have to acknowledge that that the way we've set things up is in conflict with the way living systems actually work because there is no relationship there.
And so the idea of getting clear on principles is to identify at a root cause level where the sources of change need to come from.
The other principles, I'll just mention them by name briefly and then maybe talk about one other one. But the other ones are the idea of balance systems need to be in balance.

The idea of place in my language honors community in place, living systems existing place. And so a human economy needs somehow to be connected to and relevant to place both geological reality and cultural history of place.
You think about globalization that has run run rough shot over that principle and no wonder the globalization turns out isn't working so well because it's in conflict with that principle.
Another principle from living systems is is known as the edge effect. And you know, we hear a lot about the importance of diversity.

Diversity happens in living systems at the edges between different systems. So for example, where a river meets a notion is a marsh and a marsh land is filled with diversity and diversity is is the source of life. It's also where danger exists. But, but but living systems have an abundance of life at the edges.

So what does that say about a human economy and the edge between, for example, one industry and another, or the edge between the public sector and the private sector or the philanthropic sector and the public sector.
Another principle is.
And here's one that I kind of made up in the context of human economies, I in my language, it's is holistic wealth. So some economy is largely about the.
At least the way we've thought about it is the the creation of wealth and yet we've reduced that to the creation of money. We think that the purpose of the economy is to get money.
And so this is a reminder that the true wealth is not money money is a human artifact, but, but wealth needs to be holistically understood.
And then another one is again in my language robust circulation. This is the idea that that an economy like a living system needs to behave like a healthy metabolism.
It's not merely circular thinking, although circular flows are important. It's actually much more important to think about metabolism as needing healthy inputs.

So the food into the system needs to be the right food and healthy food, not toxic food. The way is going out of the system can't spoil the nest. So too much CO2 in the atmosphere is in conflict with living systems principles.
It can't possibly be in alignment with a sustainable economy and so forth.
I did want to just I don't know if I probably haven't mentioned all eight of them, but I'm, you know, I don't want to sort of blab on here too long you get the idea they're all on.
Yeah, it's great. John and just to interject you've articulated six of the eight leaving two remaining one is empowered participation and one is innovative adaptive responsive.
So I just since we're going through my figured why not round it out.

Yeah, put them out there. I mean, innovative responsive. That's sort of a completely non controversial one, right? I mean, I think the, but but again, the importance of small business and entrepreneurs in contrast with the importance of monopolies and big industrial, powerful giants.
We, we have public policies that tend to support the monopolists because they have lobbying power and much more than we support entrepreneurs and small businesses.
This is not just an opinion that wow, we should do it differently. This is saying, well, that's actually the way living systems work. So we need to do it differently.
And empowered participation. I'll just comment very quickly.
You know, this one is quite profound. Again, this is a description of real living systems, a quality of real living systems.
And what's true about them is that all parts of that system are empowered or self-empowered to participate in the health of that system.
That's not just good for that part. That's good for the health of the system.
So, for example, I always, when I give talks, I say, well, if my feet are not empowered to participate in the circulation of oxygen in my body, that's terrible for my feet.
But that's also terrible for me because I won't be able to walk. And if I can't walk, I can't fulfill my potential as a human being.
So this gets to this whole issue of inequality. Inequality is no longer simply a moral question that we can have different opinions on.
It's actually a direct threat to systemic health. And all you have to do is look at what's happened in the world in the last 12 months to see that that's actually true.
But living systems principles would tell us that inequality that is so extreme that it disempowers the participation of the broad populations of the world,
and the world of the world, to contribute to and receive benefits from the system means that systemic health is undermined. And ultimately, it will hurt all parts of the system.

So I think we're seeing that play out in the real world. And rather than debate whether we can afford to, you know, whether we need to do austerity or whether we can afford the debt, we need to start by saying, well, we can't afford to have half of the planet disempowered from the health of the economy.
That economy will not survive.
Yeah, thank you very much for running through that. And of course, for emphasizing the critical importance of the empowered participation.
And look, just because there's an ecological reason behind why empowered participation is critical, that doesn't mean that there's not also a moral.
Appalition, right? Isn't it wonderful that they're aligned?
Yes, yes.

So we don't have to debate the moral, because, you know, for some reason, you know, I mean, obviously, I'm pretty confident most people that have tuned into this conversation would have a shared view on the moral question.
But that isn't a shared view across the world, or we wouldn't be, we wouldn't tolerate the current levels of inequality.
And I think a lot of the people in the capitalist system that tolerated would really prefer it not be there.
They would just argue that fixing it, you know, the cure will be worse than the disease, as opposed to literally thinking that this extreme inequality is a positive attribute.

Yeah, it's so interesting. And that that kind of gets at a question I want to ask you, and I'll formulate it with a couple of steps here. I, by the way, just love the edge effect and abundance piece as one of the eight principles, because it reminds me of my permaculture studies.
So, 25 years ago, right, and that was a really important piece that Bill Molison articulated.
And the robust circulation, of course, reminds me of the work by our mutual departed friend Bernard Leotard with his book Future of Money.
And I want to chat about that in a few minutes.

But as you were describing the metabolism metaphor for this robust circulation requirement, it made me think that the, the hyper accumulation of financial resources might be very much like the hyper accumulation of toxins in a body or an ecosystem.
And I wanted to, I wanted to ask you to riff on that for a little bit.
Yeah.
So, I mean, you introduced a couple of thoughts, you know, key thoughts. One is that, first of all, I should say, these are not, these eight are not the kind of correct answer.
They're, they're a map. And as Nora Bateson reminded me recently, the map is not the territory, which is a famous expression that goes back, I forget to, to who wrote that.

But they're a map that is useful to me. It's proven to be useful to others, but it doesn't mean that it's correct and an accurate map. It's a, it's a tool that can be used for our collective learning.

And secondly, it's not linear that, you know, we're dealing with a complex system. So it's not like let's go with principle number one, check principle number two, check, they all interrelate together.
So the, the, the idea of wealth accumulation being in conflict with circulation is also in conflict with imbalance. It's also in conflict with, um,

empower our rather honor, community in place because of all the money is sitting in an account on Wall Street. It's obviously not circulating out into the capillaries of the system. So, the, the massive accumulation of wealth in a very few hands is probably in conflict with all eight principles. If we really thought through it, but, you know, the term, necrosis, I think I'm saying correctly, where you know, blood clots.

What, you know, whether it's toxins building up, we could have an interesting debate about whether money is, is a toxin.
